question: Question_01_(d)
sols:
Taking the derivative of $h(x)$ and using the chain rule, we get:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle h'(x) = \exp(f(x))f'(x) + 2f(x)f'(x)\end{align*} Substituting
$x = 1$ and using the given values of $f(1)$ and $f'(1)$ gives:

\begin{align*}
h'(1) &= \exp(f(1))f'(1) + 2f(1)f'(1)\\
&= 5\exp(2) + 2(2)(5)\\
&= 5e^{2} + 20\end{align*} Therefore,
${\color{blue}\displaystyle h'(1) = 5e^{2} +20}$.
hints: Remember to use the chain rule when differentiating $h(x)$.
